I am still early on in the game, I think.  It's not bad for a top-down turn-based tactics sci-fi adventure.  However, I feel a bit like I settled, because the story-line is not particularly engaging to me, as it consists of verbose texts which, while obtained by speaking to static characters, seem more like designer signposts.  I do not mind reading text if it's engaging and presented in an interesting way. I am a veteran of the early text adventures from the 1980's and a fan of Planescape: Torment, so I enjoy a good yarn.

The battles are fun though. 

I am a bit confused by the tag, "Rogue-like" which is one of the tags associated with this game; as I grew up with Nethack, Rogue, et al., which are true rogue-likes.  The battles here are not random generated levels, with random items which I figured would give it more replayability.  I read some posts by the developers explaining the tag rogue-like means the save game system is rogue-like, which means there is only a single persistent save file per campaign.  The save file is not so restrictive though, the developers have it tamed in such a way as you can replay the battle before accepting the save, or quit without saving which allows you to restart and replay from where you last saved. That is the only thing that is somewhat rogue-like --and a forgiving rogue-like, at that-- as far as I can tell. 

If you want a turn-based tactics adventure, and care less for an engaging story, then this is recommended. However, if you want both fun gameplay and an engaging story then you may want to shop around some more before settling.

Steam do a lot of things that annoy me. One such thing is making me look through a queue of games that I probably won't like and don't want, just to get the stupid free trading cards every time they do a sale. However, in this case they did me a service. 

This game was on the list, and as I like turn-based strategy I stuck it on my wishlist. I didn't buy it until about a year later when there was an offer on it but I wish I'd bought it earlier.

Templar Battleforce is a turn based squad game where you control a team of different classes in various missions against an alien menace. There are several things that I like about it:

Firstly, the different classes feel pretty distinct. There are a few that do similar things but even they have subtle perks that make them different. Maybe not as individualised as the classes on the XCOM games but still a nice selection.

Secondly, despite the fact that I am not finished there is a pretty good storyline, which is often missing in games at this pricepoint. There is a whole lore and universe that is fleshed out fairly well during the missions themselves and in a few expository scenes between the main combat.

Speaking of the missions, there are a lot of them. I recently got the achievement for completing 30 missions and I think there are still 10+ to go (excuse me devs if I'm selling this short). It definitely feels like value for money in terms of longevity. Considering that there are several different difficulty levels and an ironman mode there is also some replayability too.

There are other things I like, such as the music, which ramps up the drama well as you progress through a mission. There are times where you are surrounded or struggling to work out how to defend yourself against a wave of "Xeno" and the music definitely adds to the tension.

I am playing through at normal difficulty and that feels like the perfect challenge already. There are times I have had to reset and redo a mission when I make a mistake like leaving a tactical point undefended, or walking into a horde of tough enemies with just a scout to fend for himself. Even when I have to do this it rarely feels like the game is picking on me, and when i refine my tactics a little I can plough through, but it feels like an accomplishment rather than a chore. Once I complete it I will definitely see if I can handle a tougher difficulty.

To add a little balance to an otherwise positive review, some of the mechanics are a little hard to understand at first. It can take a little effort or some looking through discussion boards to work out what is going on. Even with this relatively minor complaint, the developers are still incredibly helpful. Despite the game being out for a long time already, the two queries I have had have been answered by the devs within minutes of me asking them, and looking at other discussions this is not a fluke.

Overall, if you're a fan of turn based games then it is worth paying the full amount. Even if you're not, get it on sale.

34899222.review:
TL:DR
It's still rough around the edges, but fun on easy difficulties if you don't think too hard on the mechanics.

For $10 I was a tad skeptical that this game could really take up my time. But when I got into it, the time wasn't spent on playing the game... 
It was spent on dissecting every little aspect of gameplay mechanics up until the cultists missions.

I really like dice rolling system, as a whole it's a solid 10/10 for how it "feels" when just jumping into the fray and letting things take their course. Attack an enemy! Hit or miss? Feels slightly more forgiving than say... Xcom. You don't have to understand how it works, it works well either way.

It's very entertaining to anyone who likes options for the sheer fact that there's options. Because there's a LOT of options. And just about any way you want to play it is valid for completing almost every mission.

There's some important information I need to impart however. If you're anything like me, you like to optimize. You like to Min/Max. You can't stand it if you complete the objective just under a perfect score. This is where I feel the game has a terrible flaw, and if the devs are still alive out there, I'd like them to take this to heart.

In order to gain new skills and equipment, you need requisition points. Requisition points are awarded upon completion of each mission you do. However, there is the possibility of earning EXTRA requisition points, and it's very clear from the size of the requisition tree that you're going to need as many points as possible. So, how do you earn the extra points for that sweet sweet "perfect" score? Two ways: Kill as many enemies as possible in as few turns as possible (as the score is based on an average kills per turn) AND complete the mission in general in as few turns as possible. From here, the games compatibility with all of its "possibilities and options" goes down the drain.

Picking anything that is slower and/or safer is immediately going to be less effective in the long run. You absolutely must rush every mission while strategically picking which spots are worth stopping on to potentially snipe some poor xeno who happened to be on your speed path. The best Kills per Turn bonus I've ever gotten was 8%, and that was at 6 kills per turn. The best speed bonus you can earn is a WHOPPING 20%!! And that doesn't just apply to RP, it applies to EXP too! Getting that massive bonus is possible on almost every mission, so going without it just seems like a bad idea.

Now since the goal is to go as fast as possible, this limits which character classes are valid to play with. Obviously scouts seem like the go to pick, but they're so fragile they explode instantly. Sensorkit scans supposedly keep them aware of enemies, but the scans cost as much AP as a shot and a ton of heat too. Combine this with the fact that A:running further causes more heat and B: you can't stop running because you NEED to complete the objective as fast as possible and C: you can't use sensorkits while overheated means you're out in the open just hoping that a xeno doesn't pop out the one dark tile you can't see 5 tiles away from you.
Engineers also have sensor kits, but have far too many responsibilities to free them up, are too expensive to deploy more, and have too many skills needed to properly defend themselves AND go exploring.
Soldiers are pretty go to with rallying charge, but they'll soon suffer heat problems and slow down.
Hydra and Neptune are fancy soldiers with a higher deploy cost, but without the soldiers practicality (Dalan Ortho 4life).
Berserker is like the mix of your captain and paladin... good at melee attacking stuff with various buffs and debuffs but can't heal.
Paladins are a godsend which stop for no one and don't overheat easily (until you need to start healing).
Then there's your captain, who also stops for no one when built as a melee tank. He can speed buff himself and run through maps to do all the objectives for you.

Look, I like what's here, but the game doesn't properly incentivise the use of other classes. I play this on Demanding difficulty. My sole loadout is always Captain, Dalan Ortho, and Paladin. Squad sizes are too small to make use of other classes, and the starting SP is never enough to get more than one expensive unit (which means I end up getting my pally, but never an engineer). Missions have tactical points, but the missions never last long enough for them to matter. You go in with who you have, maybe recruit 1 extra guy if there's an easy tactical point, and it's over. The game suffers from the fact that it only has the campaign (which must be rushed) and no free play.


SOOOOO, here's my suggestions. For the reward system, make bonus objectives gives +5 bonus Exp AND Rp. For the kill system, remove the kills per turn and install a kill threshold system. I'm thinking along the lines of the threshold being hp based? So in a mission, deal 400 hp in damage as the goal, and hp is only added to the counter when the enemy is killed. Got a skittering down to 1 hp? Doesn't count. Kill it, then you get its hp value added to the counter. Going over the target value will earn bonus %, which will hit a cap (I recommend 20%, like your turn completion bonus).

For the start of missions, give out a little more starting SP. Second to this, give an option recall or add troops based on SP cost. Conversely, tweak the costs of troops so that they're cheaper, and the difference in cost isn't literally 50% of a whole unit. For some of the bigger missions you are FORCED to use some crappy soldier or scout you've never used before, but you're unable to swap them out because there's never enough starting SP. If squad sizes were a little bigger, you could decide whether you want 3 cheap units or 2 special ones.

A free play or challenge mode would be nice. I would love to see how different setups fair against waves of enemies that get progressively stronger. Maybe add this mode as a reward for completing your first optional mission in the campaign.

Lastly, auto-block is really powerful, not sure if it's OP though. The stat is basically non-negotiable. Armor is however, in conjuction with deflection. Unfortunately anything with low deflection and high armor defeats the purpose of wearing it since everything will penetrate it, causing half the armor value to be lost. As such the only practical option is to pick high deflection suits with low or moderate armor. Not sure how to balance it for really low deflection values.

33680493.review:
[h1]One of the Best Designed Games Ever Rating: 10 of 10[/h1]

Nearly every moment of my time during the first 30 hours of playthrough was filled with this thought "If I were designing this game, I'd include a game mechanic that did X". Immediately after each of these thoughts "X" happened. I really couldn't be more pleased.  I'll break this down into a categorical deep-dive:

[b]Strategy & Fun: 10 of 10[/b]

This game has kept me playing for about 100 hours thus far (my hours currently appear inflated due to AFK time. This game has a rich set of rules that govern how combat plays out. At the easiest couple of difficulties, you can survive without knowing the details. However, the well-crafted ruleset (mechanics) lend importance to every single decision you make and nuance layerd upon nuance.

The game has many difficulty levels which not only add immesurable amounts of replay value, but also caters toward those who are masters of strategy as well as the novice more interested in the story, and everything in-between.  I always enjoy myself when playing this game, win or lose. 

[b]Music: 8/10[/b]

The music is somewhat simple, while also appropriately bombastic, and anxiety-enducing. (This is particularly the case when I've just realized I'm surrounded, out of range of my turrets and supplies are running low.) It loops in a simple pattern, which I orginally thought would drive me mad, but surprisingly I haven't been bothered by the repetition a single time. Consider that this entire game was made by three brothers and tell me you aren't impressed that at least one of them had enough musical talent to do this.

[b]Art & Graphics: 8/10[/b]

The graphics on this game are typical of an indie studio. Think around the range of a Sega Genesis game in terms of detail . However, the art is extremely good and sets the stage for the plot and overall ambiance. I'm not a huge fan of GPU-intensive games anyway so I'm pleased enough with the quality here.

[b]Storyline: 8/10[/b]

I won't spoil the plot here but know that the story builds as you progress in a satisfying way. I never felt a break in the immersion while playing due to a plot foible or poorly written line of text.  The game is consistently good in this department, and actually wasn't predictable to me. One nice thing is this game takes place in a broader ecosystem of games and so I feel I get value out of learning about this portion as it will apply to earlier/later titles.

[b]Replay Value: 10/10[/b]

Ok, so I've mentioned I spent 100+ hours so far? Yeah, that's on two difficulty levels I've played. I am a slower player of this game. There are totally different sets of strategies that would end maps more quickly but I prefer slower, methodical, alien bloodbaths.  I expect to put another [b]700+ hours[/b] into this game. Why? Let's count the replay-enhancing options: 

1. There are many story paths you can take that aren't available in a single playthrough.

2. There is a limited amount of a resource you use to give team-wise specializations (called "RQ" in the game) that means you effectively have *many* mutually exclusive options as you play through an entire game. Trying to get through the game without one branch of skills/items gives you more room to play with other abilities/toys.

3. There are something like 9 difficulty levels. I skipped over Easy as it isn't massively different than Normal and I didn't consider myself enough of a novice to start on Easy. However, the other difficulty levels are distinct enough in their challenges that I intend to play through each at least once. (The higher difficulties will take longer, and some permanently punish failure so they'll take many times more hours to play through.)

4. There is a new game+ mode through which you can continue on the same or a different difficutly with all of your skills/levels/gear that you earned throughout the game but the enemies' levels scale as well. This is the mechanism through which you can get all of the possibly abilities/gear on a single squad. However, I've enjoyed playing with famine more than feast so I haven't even tried this yet.

5. There are new levels occasionally added to the post-campgain section, for free! Think DLC worth 20% of the buying price of your favorite game being released every few months or so, but at no cost to you. Pretty sweet. The set of missions they have out right now are at least as good as the main campaign.

6. There are Steam achivements that might require a special setup to acquire. You could burn some hours hunting these down for sure.

[b]Polish: 6*/10[/b]

Now, here's really the only weak point of this game. It has some weird bugs every now and then, but I personally have never encountered any that broke my game. (I have been saddened to get a new item only to discover it was bugged such that it took no effect.) However, the asterisk I'm applying here is because the game developers are continually fixing bugs as they are reported (and I mean like within hours of the report) and adding new content, again, for free! This is truly the game that keeps on giving.  Also, if you consider the team size (3) of the developers, this is a rare masterpiece.

[b]Conclusion[/b]

In closing I definitely think it is worth the asking price of $50. Wait, it's only [b]$10[/b]!? WHY HAVEN'T YOU PURCHASED THIS YET WHAT IS WRONG WITH YOU??

A turn-based tactical RPG which is rather plainly an homage to the Warhammer 40k universe. Lead a squad of genetically engineered Templars in the massive powered armor suit against hordes of xenos, heretical human forces, and hyper-advanced machines. A wide variety of classes abound for your Templars to choose from, with new types of armor, weapons, relics, "call-downs", and other bonuses made available to that class and, in some cases, other classes as well.

You face unending waves of enemies which you will cut apart, burn to a crisp, or blast to pieces in droves. Managing your unit's overwatch as you move to achieve your objectives is reminiscent of the Space Hulk games. Achieving the main objectives, as well as bonuses objectives, awards you with points you can use to recruit more Templars, or upgrade existing Templar class lines. Overall, recommended. A fun title for a reasonable price.

If you're a fan of sci-fi in style of WH40K, with a desire for a top-down squad based RPG version of the space hulk board game, then you've potentially found what you're looking for.

Features:
- You dictate which troop type & skills your squad will gain access to. e.g. Scout, Engineer, heavy weapon specialist (Machine gun, flamethrower), melee specialist.

important game mechanics to be aware of are:
 HEAT: Every action generates heat, and you can only dissipate some of that heat each turn. Doing nothing means you loose more heat than if you only move around or fire your gun. This is important as a full heat guage means you take damage until you let your mech cool down.
NO UNDO MOVE: you can cancel a characters move whilst they are part way through moving, but you can't undo an accidental move. So you need to be aware of who you've selected when you click move. This game is a good TRPG, but for me is ruined by a single game mechanic. Overheating.

Basically, whenever in combat you move, attack, use abilities or run in flames (duh), you build up Heat in your mechanized armor. Which would be fine as a mechanic if it was balanced correctly.

If a character's Heat reaches the top of its armor's tolerance, it will go in Overheating, in this status, a character won't be able to use certain skills, will have penalties to combat features, and will take damage over time based on how much Overheat there is.

Point is, Heat takes quite a lot of time to dissipate, and to make it dissipate, you have to make your soldiers do nothing at all, or barely anything, for many turns, this while enemies are rightly swarming at you from all sides. 

If you don't care and just run for it and let your characters oveheat, they will lose more and more health each turn, and before or later, since missions a bit further in the game are pretty long, will die not because of enemy damage, but because of Overheating! While if they have to cool down and sit doing nothing for some turns, the enemies will tear them apart most likely.

This single mechanic, in my humble opinion, totally kills the combat, which is the large part of this title's entire gameplay. I really like the setting, the style, and the management mechanics, but after i failed my campaign just because of Overheating decimating my teams, and making me lose veteran soldiers i carefully built, i can't stand this anymore.

In short: Highly reccomended if you like turn based tactics.

---

Templar Battleforce (TB), one of the best turn based tactics games I've played in a very long time. Fallout Tactics (2001) and Jagged Alliance 2 (1999) come to my mind. A more recent contender may be Bionic Dues (2013, check it out if you like TB).


The gameplay:
You lead your squad of mechwarriors into battle against different kinds of aliens and human traitors. Different missions will allow a different number of templars you can deploy, ranging from 3-6. Somtimes you will find "tact points" which can be captured by your engineer to deploy more templars and a wide range of ordnance.
You can outfit your mechs with many different weapons, armor and supplemental modules, improve stats and learn many different talents (attacks, buffs, debuffs, healing, area scans, sentry turrets etc.). The types depend on the templars class and your progression in the tech tree. The tech tree is pretty huge, alowing great customization of the 8 classes. 
Mission goals are diverse, so you want to use the right mechs for the job. For example, if you have to search an area for something then you better bring a scout. If you have to defend a position then soldier, neptune (heavy weapons) and hydra (flames!) are a better choice.
In battle, you take turns against the enemy using action and movement points. Comparing attack accuracy, penetration and damage against defence, deflection, armor and resist.

The missions are great: Full of "oh shit"-moments, heroic last stands, tragic losses and triumphant victories. Hold positions against a brutal alien onslaught, purge a town from infestation and secure it, storm a bunker and try to stop the menace to humanity... there are many missions and branching story paths. After 33 hours I haven't even finished the game.  Shifting mission goals keep things interesting and tense.

The story is rather deep for a game of this kind and provides a nice background for the action. The game plays in the Trese Brothers' Star Traders universe.

The music is suprisingly good for a low budget title and the sound effects fit well.
The visuals are clean and the UI is comortable to use.
The game has 7 difficulties and a permadeath option.


Can’t say anything bad about it, only the visuals may put off some people but you can see for yourself in the screenshots.
Highly recommendend!

[b]An overview specially written for players of Trese Brothers' previous title [i]Heroes of Steel[/i]:[/b]

I initially grabbed this game and its cousin, HoS (a fantasy title by the same publisher/developer and using the same engine), because they reminded me of top-down half-board game, half-roleplaying game modules from my youth, such as TSR's [i]Dungeons & Dragons[/i] and [i]Star Frontiers[/i], which came with glossy full-color maps and flat cardboard playing pieces representing characters, monsters and other things. And additionally because in the case of [i]Templar Battleforce[/i], I was also reminded of its obvious [i]Warhammer 40,000[/i] inspiration.

Those first impressions seem to have been on target, as after many hours of playtime in both titles, whether by design or by accident, they still evoke that comparison for me — except the "playing pieces" are well-animated and the game master comes with the software.

Unlike its fantasy-themed cousin, the several campaigns that come packaged with [i]Templar Battleforce[/i] are written in the same genre as WH40K: grim, dark, military science-fiction. So be forewarned, it lacks its cousin's commendably intimate character development and interpersonal drama. On the bright side, you'll find a lot more wonderful science-fiction influences bubbling beneath its surface than just those of WH40K; fans of BattleTech, Dune, and even Battlestar Galactica might be pleased as well.

28562317.review:
For everyone who’s allergic to reading, here’s the TL;DR version:
If you like turn-based tactics game in which you can customize your units according to your preferred playstyle, this is the game for you. The game features over 50 levels in which you fight various alien and human enemies, leading to a playtime of about 30-35h for your first playthrough.
Your Templars level up, get better and learn additional abilities which – if used correctly – will bring you victory. New equipment and additional classes are unlocked via a research tree. The difficulty settings allow beginners as well as pros a challenging but enjoyable time with the game.
Buy it, it’s absolutely worth the 10 bucks.

Some more details now:
[h1]What’s the game about? [/h1]
In the grim future of Templar Battleforce the remaining humans go on what gets called the great Exodus after the Great Galactic War to settle new planets far away from their devastated home.
You’re controlling a group of Templars, members of a martial order, who pilot giant battle suits and are sworn to protect the human colonists. You’re bigger and stronger than any normal human and basically the only one who has a proper chance in fighting the threats the vast galaxy has to offer. 
Granted, the presentation is a little bit dry: Lots of completely unvoiced dialogues, no shiny CGI cutscenes and relatively unimpressive graphics. If you’re willing to read you will soon see, however, the devs put a lot of effort into the lore of the game (you can also jump straight from battle to battle of course).
The story is motivating enough though to keep you playing and the slight Warhammer 40k vibe going on also is pretty cool.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The core of the game of course is the fighting. You send your heavily armed Templars on space ships, through cities or into a seemingly empty desert. Each soldier has a certain movement allowance, measured in tiles of which the levels are made of. The action points are used for attacking as well as using buffs, building defensive turrets and more. The game therefore is turn-based, requiring you to end your turn if you used up all points and let the enemy act – similar to for example XCOM.
The mission types vary: Sometimes you have to quickly push to a certain objective, for example to destroy a xeno lair, another time you have to capture and hold points on the map or wait for support. Usually you are on the offensive and should therefore avoid getting entangled in prolonged fights. Captured tactical points produce supply points which allow you to call in more members of your squad or buy ordnance like medi kits.
Your squad consists of various specialists, always lead by your captain. You got the soldier who combines good accuracy and range with a variety of buffs and the extremely useful overwatch ability to control zones. Scouts are great long-rang-combat units and can be developed in either a scout or a sniper direction.
Then there’re engineers, the only ones who can capture points and erect turrets. The Hydra equipped with a deadly flamethrower and the ability to set whole areas ablaze. The Paladin, a melee warrior with a lot of useful buffs and healing abilities. The Berserker as the high damage melee unit and the Neptune, a heavy weapon specialist – a little bit like the big brother of the soldier.
The interface is unobtrusive and shows the range for movement, shooting and buffs of all your units; you can also get detailed info about the enemy types you’re facing. Enemy variety meanwhile is decent, the majority of your playtime you will fight the Terrox xeno which look like your standard alien species and come in different versions: from small crawlers over ranged units to some really brutal late-game elites. Occasionally you find yourself opposed by some human adversaries and then, finally, you will face the Narvidians. A hive-mind race which was the cause for the already mentioned great galactic war.

[h1]Progression system + research[/h1]
If one of your soldiers reaches a new level, you will be able to spend points on various attributes which either increase your health points, your chance to hit with a particular kind of weapon, your chance to get critical hits or your defence in case an enemy gets the chance to attack you. Not all attributes are similarly important to every class of course and some classes have special ones like the scout’s stealth or the Paladin’s medic attribute.
You will also be able to spend points on your Templars’ abilities, improving them or unlocking completely new talents. Generally, it’s worth thinking about which role you want each of your units to play and put their level-up points accordingly. You can easily recruit two soldiers and make one into a heavy hitter who likes to get close and personal while your other guy focusses on overwatch and defensive buffs.
Finally, there’s the equipment screen where you can give your happy soldiers new guns, a new shield or an improved armour. More advanced weapons don’t always deal more damage, there’re also ones which trade damage for higher accuracy or some additional elemental damage. Some armour may be really tough but slows you down etc.
To get new equipment and to unlock new talents, you have to use some requisition points in what basically is something like a research tree. You won’t be able to unlock everything so you have to carefully choose. In which direction do you want to focus your captain? Pure melee or with a sidearm? Does your soldier need grenades? Do you want to unlock the Neptune class or rather put more points into the Berserker? And doesn’t the Paladin desperately need a new weapon?

[h1]Technical stuff[/h1]
Loading times are extremely fast, the game runs stable and there basically aren’t any bugs – performance overall is great.
While I like the art style and atmosphere of the game, you can see by looking at some screenshots or videos the graphic isn’t exactly what you would call beautiful. If you don’t really care that much about shiny graphics anyway as long as the game’s great that’s not a concern ofc.
As mentioned before, none of the dialogues are voiced; the sound effects are mediocre and the soundtrack, while fitting, gets old pretty fast. I turned off all sounds for the game and just listened to some music while playing. 

[h1]In conclusion…[/h1]
If you like these kind of turn-based games and the futuristic scenario there isn’t really any reason not to buy this (maybe you even played Space Hulk in the past). It works so incredibly well, all classes and abilities feel useful and the mechanics are easy to get into. Building up your own squad of super soldiers which you can name, customize and level-up in any way you want feels great.
Visually it’s not the most impressive and the story and its presentation won’t knock your socks off but the game itself just feels so satisfying.
The devs are very active, regularly checking the forums and fixing any bugs people encounter; they even add new content to the game and generally have an open ear for the community – exemplary!
One playthrough will probably take you between 30 and 35 hours, depending on your skill. Due to the way the requisition tree is designed the game has a lot of replay value for everyone who wants to go at it again using different strategies or previously not unlocked classes. Trying a higher difficulty level may also be an incentive; for players like me who are only…ehm…passable at these kind of games easy or normal are still enjoyable without being frustrating while pros can jump directly to the higher ones. Another thing to do after finishing the game is replaying the game with your veteran squad: The game offers a new game plus mode where you keep your experienced Templars, your equipment and your research level and play through the whole campaign again, if desired on a different difficulty level.

I picked Templar Battleforce up whilst it was on sale for a tiny amount (I think either £2 or £3) and I thoroughly recommend it, it's a great game!

-GAMEPLAY-

The best way I can describe this game is to say it is a simpler version of XCOM (in a good way). There's no base-building, it is simply mission after mission of your squad of troops against the enemy. From my experience of it so far you are normally massively outnumbered by the enemy on each mission, but to make up for this each unit in your squad is far stronger than the enemy. You'd expect 1 of your units to face off on its own against 4-8 of the enemy at once and usually come out victorious (depending on the unit's class). There are a range of mission types, such as survive x number of turns, reach a certain point, capture parts of a map, escort civilians etc.

-RPG-

The RPG element of the game is awesome, and you really can specialise each unit how you want as you spend ability and stat points. For example, I have one Soldier (long range unit) in my team who specialises in the overwatch ability, so that he can guard captured bases by himself. Each victory earns you Research Points which can go into unlocking new classes, or unlocking new features for existing classes - each class has several different specialities (e.g. your Captain can specialise in close combat, support, ranged fire, or as a grenade specialist).

-STORYLINE-

I've been playing this game for just over 13 hours at the time of writing and I'm already hooked. I won't give anything away but I will say although it's not the most advanced storyline, it's good enough to keep you interested. I also like the fact that there's permadeath for your characters - I am already massively attached to each and every one of my characters and refuse to let any die for that reason.

-IMPROVEMENTS-

At the start of most missions your team (usually 5 or 6, although this amount might increase later in the game) is pre-selected from your roster for you. You start the mission with a currency called 'SP' which can be used to immediately swap one unwanted member of your team out for one of your preferred members, but I think a massive improvement would be to just let the user pick their own team at the start of every mission. I understand for some missions you need a specific class such as an Engineer which is fine, but the user perhaps should be able to pick the rest of the team themselves after the mandatory ones.

As I've made clear though, I love this game already and this last point is just a suggested improvement to what is otherwise a fantastic game.

TL;DR - Pick this up if you want a simpler version of XCOM with awesome combat missions and good RPG progression.

26046244.review:
A very solid, "Maybe not Warhammer" game. The fluff isn't bad, but the mechanics are much more original and compelling, in my opinion. There are several major types of enemies (xenos and otherwise) that each feel different and possess different strengths and weaknesses.

The progression is interesting, and the missions are well-balanced to my findings so far - the only real flaw I'm finding is that with the Mission Completion reward system, you are strongly encouraged to stack movespeed buffs as much as you can, overheating your team constantly and not relying on skills that require you not to be overheated. This allows you to generally outrange and overwatch-spam your enemies to death as they chase you, or to simply outpace them, complete the mission in 60%-80% of the 'par' number of turns, and get a huge bonus to your XP/RP unlocks.

Also, to give you a perhaps slightly better idea of how things work than the trailers do...

That massive tree with "Unlock 1000+ unique talents and gear" is a general unlock tree for your full force. The Berserker, Paladin, Neptune, and Hydra trees unlock both a new class and gear shared with other classes, which encourages you to branch out into them based on what you plan to do with your squad. For instance, some of the best Heat capacity gear for the Engineer is on the Hydra tree.

Progression along the tech tree, of sorts, allows you to raise the level of skills and equip gear to a Templar who has sufficient level. When they level, they also gain stat points to distribute to Attributes and to Skills; each of them provides a small bonus to either a dice pool (like accuracy) or percentile (like crit chance). The choices you make for unlocks are permanent; choices for assigned gear and abilities are able to be reset and reassigned freely between missions. This means, for instance, you can have a low-level Scout specced in Quickness and Stealth for light weapons, debuffing attacks, and scouting, then as its levels increase you can swap to Strength and Tactics plus the Headshot skill for dealing massive critical damage while still being able to hit. The only thing that has any limitations on use are "Relics," pieces of gear that can only be used by one Templar at a time, some of which are amazing and some of which are "eh."

The combat system is worth reading a Steam guide on - it's not explained much unless you dig deep, but it's a system that can be loosely described as 'easy to learn, hard to master.' Part of this is that you can't be sure what sort of dice pools you're facing on the enemies, so you can't be certain of when you have 'enough' accuracy to hit reliably and can move on to other stats, as you don't receive any bonus for overshooting an enemy's defense pool that I know of.

In short, as long as you're comfortable with the faults I'm mentioned and you like Turn-Based Tactics, this game is definitely worth a buy; if you're hesitant but like the genre, it's worth a buy on sale. I've put quite a few hours into it and expect to put many more in to try out different playstyles.

Surprisingly good tactic game (that, incedently, has nothing at all to do with Warhammer, as I originally thought). It scratched the same itch as the old Incubation: Time Is Running Out: a small squad of powerful soldiers against a endless flow of mindless, relatively weak enemies.

However, it's NOT a spiritual successor to Incubation we all are waiting for :) Templat Battleforce is somewhat simplier than Incubation, because of sameness of enemies: no need to attack from behind or only attack doing enemy's turn with Overwatch. Levels are less like puzzles where you have to get everything right to pass through, because turns limit is not hard (you get bonus for completing a level under turns limit, but you do not lose if you fail to do so).

On the other hand, many elements will be familiar to anyone who played Incubation: overheating and equipment points which limit how much things a soldier can carry, for example. 

Unlike Incubation, soliders don't disappear here if they died during the mission, which makes it less painful to lose one. However, there are also no quicksave/quickload option during the battle (unless you revert to manual save-scumming, which I did at the very end of campaign), which makes longer levels a pain to replay.

Overall, I definitely recommend this game if you like tactic games, and especially if you liked Incubation.

I must also mention that this game is a surprising example of a well-made mobile port. Yes, everything is bigger-than-it-needs-to-be on PC screen, and there are some problems with mouse controls (mostly, scrolling; why was it impossible to implement hold-and-pan in battle, I can't righly imagine). But it doesn't cause much pain, and what's more important, the gameplay is NOT dumbed-down for mobiles (I guess the game is not a big hit in that market, however...).

25155478.review:
I was in a mood for strategy and blowing things up one day. I found this game while I was cruising through my queue and pretty much bought it impulsively. How'd that turn out? Surprisingly well. While I haven't gotten too far into the game yet, it did provide me with some inspiration to start a Let's Play of something that wasn't a dating sim. (And the dating sim Let's Play didn't even begin that long ago either.) 

[b]Before I get to the review, this is important to note.[/b] The thing about this game that may either attract or repel you is that it is heavily reliant on dice rolls.
With each attack, dodge, and parry, many dice get rolled under the hood. This part of the system relies on comparing successes, similar to how contested rolls work in Classic World of Darkness games. Certain dice are more likely to score successes, which are called Strong Dice. The other dice are Standard Dice.
Blocks, deflections, and critical hits function on a percentile system, where rolling under a certain number blocks damage, automatically deducts half of your armor from the damage incoming (in the case of deflection), or causes a critical hit.
Damage, however, functions pretty differently than what you'd expect. While I could explain it, it can be pretty complicated mathematically, but the short version is that the attacker has an equal chance to roll any particular number in a given damage range (26-50, for example) and the target has a few factors that reduce damage, some of which function similarly to how one generates damage rolls.

[b]Now that that is out of the way, let's get to the review.[/b]

[h1]REVIEW[/h1]
I got this game not too long after it came out of Early Access. I went into this blindly, although I had the urge to play some kind of strategy game that wasn't the ones I had been playng for years (various hacks for Shining Force games, Vandal Hearts 1 and 2, a couple others) and wanted to do something involving a sci-fi setting. After looking up some games, Templar Battleforce caught my attention as it was on sale at the time and it had generally positive reviews. So I got it.

It took me a while to get used to the mechanics of moving around, the order of operations during a turn (AP usage also uses MP, but not vice versa), the concept of heat (well, it makes sense to me at least), and trying (and failing a lot of the time) to master the art of stealth. After learning all of that, the game works pretty solidly. There are times where I do dumb things (I was recording a second video of an Ironman playthrough, but derped for a moment and closed one of my templars in airlock doors and killed him [b]ARGH![/b]), but for some of my riskiest actions, I do well. And it's rewarding when that happens. 

Upsides of this game include many diffculty settings to play on (my playthrough is on Normal, the next to easiest setting, although I've been going through a save that's on Brutal, which is three steps above Normal, and there's three more difficulties after Brutal), a pretty good variety of classes to use for the composition of your squad (I'm finding myself tending towards the use of [i]Hail Hydra[/i], who burns every last alien, alien lover, and alien monstrosity they see [b]HERETICS![/b]... Oh, sorry, 40k flashbacks), and some interesting lore.

Downsides of this game include the lack of mod support (which, while the developers are working on it, may be a long shot at getting it to happen), some of the classes perhap feeling underwhelming for a good while until you progress far enough into the game (I'm looking at you, [i]Neptune[/i]), and RNG-sus occasionally laughing in your face and smacking you with massive damage and critical misses (just misses that happen when you need that one hit to either kill the alien or alien lover or to stop them in their tracks [b]PURGE THE HERESY AUGH![/b]... not the 40k spasms again).

[b][i]JANUARY 9 UPDATE[/i][/b]
I'm nearing what I think is the end of the game, before New Game+. A good number of updates have arrived since the last time I touched this review (as of this writing, Update #62 just came out), and I think I should cover some of those.

A few new enemy types have been introduced. While I have yet to go back through levels with humans and seeing the new human enemy types, I've dealt with a good chunk of new aliens of the type that I wrote of previously. I'm just now coming across the Narvidian menace, so my experience with them is limited enough for me to not really know the difference unless another type of Narvidian is introduced. With that said, the new types are nice to see.

Along with new enemy types, we've also gained new options for our Templars. Engineers can use equipment specialized for burninating the countryside [b]TROGDORRRRR![/b] (ah, sorry, old Internet things) such as flame turrets and flamer pistols. Hydras can use the special flame tank armor that engineers can use to further increase their fire damage. Berserks can now dual-wield axes to decimate foes (running around with axes that bypass a lot of armor is nice offensively, but not the best defensively). Paladins can use big two-handed shock hammers, which I've found quite fun for smiting a lot of foes.

Neptunes... well, they've been improved in that the Overwatch abilities between Soldiers and Neptunes now differ, and that their weapons tend to have higher armor piercing capability. With that said, they're still a little behind, but they'll be caught up at some point after the enemy updates are done.

In addition to modifying the units, some map changes have been done too. I have yet to see the new versions of the maps that were affected (or at least, that I notice), but it's good to know. Also, UI changes have been made to make things more convenient.

Overall, I give this game a 9/10 for fans of the genre. It's pretty well-assembled, and updates to the game are free and plentiful. Enemies are just as plentiful as the sand. Also, there's Space Hulk vibes somewhere. Vae Victus!

This is a decent turn-based strategy game.  Stylistically it's a mix of WH40K and Incubation, with powered armor and an endless stream of bugs coming to get you.

The game biggest fault is what some would consider a feature: it loves to throw numbers at you.  One of the very first screens you see is the difficulty screen, which offers 7 different levels, expressing each as a collection of levels and percentages.  If something attacks you, the computer will consider your dodge, block, parry, armor strength, deflection, and "damage soak" when determining if and how badly you're hit.  And there's flames, plasma, and bio-poison too.

Consider the character screen: one of the 7 sections on the character sheet reads: "Melee Defense = 16 strong + 9 standard :: Weapon/Shield Parry (4s) + Warrior (12s) + Armor Evade (0) + Evasion (8) + Parry Bonus(1)".

All of these mechanics make the game muddled and uncertain, not deeper.  It's explained in the "library", but why bury the player in numbers when it just boils down to "more is better"?

The UI is generally clean, though there are some questionable choices.  For example, you can respec your soldiers at any time, by resetting them to base stats.  It would have been easier to work with "+" and "-" buttons instead of "+" and "reset".  The equipment screens have you choose between "what you can equip now" and "what you could equip someday", which makes it awkward to compare what you have with what's available if you spend "requisition points".  (Should flip between "equip now" and everything, with the "available someday" in a different color scheme.)

The graphics are decent, though sometimes it's hard to tell which squares are open, which are walls, and which are obstacles that can be fired over but not moved through.

The separation of "movement points" and "action points" is an interesting idea.  By encouraging move-then-shoot, you have to think a bit more about how far to move.

The AoE damage is a bit dodgy, as it's not always clear which cells will be affected by attacks at certain angles.  Some sort of attack overlay would have been useful.

Despite its shortcomings I had fun playing it, so I'm giving it a thumbs-up.

23840402.review:
For reference, I just beat the campaign for the first time (I played in normal). I usually like turn by turn strategy and tactical games like civilization, fire emblem, shining force, ...

Templar Batteleforce is a tactical rpg type game which is mostly a sequence of fights with team building in between fights; in the same way your typical fire emblem would be. 

It took me about 40 hours to beat the game for the first time which makes the game an appropriate length in my opinion. It is about 40-ish battles. The game features many difficulty level and probably has a reasonnable replay value. I plan on at least playing the full game a second time, and probably more to explore different team builds.

What really did the game for me is how battles are constructed. Essentially the better you "score" in a battle, the more experience and RP (essentially money) you get out of the battle. The score is essentially computed depending on how fast you accomplished the objectives, how many ennemie you killed and how many secondary objective (often unknown to you in advance) you accomplished. This gives a sense of urgency in the battles, encourages you to explore, but exploring is dangerous.

An interesting mechanic in the game is the concept of "heat points". Essentially all movement and action a character does makes its suit heat. And when overheated, he starts taking damage, losing ability to perform some types of action, or completely shut down. It is something that usually does not come in the way too much, but it is also something that you can not ignore.

The team build part of the game is interesting. Essentially the number of "points" you can allocate to characters really mean that you can not max-out a character. You have to make hard choices. For instance, you pretty much have to choose between a scout that can scan large portion of the maps and move fast, and a scout that deals massive damage at a distance; you can try a middle ground but it might not be best. Similarly with the engineer, either you get a tact point expert to help take and control tactical points (which are supply point on the map), or you make a battle engineer which buffs your units and is reasonnably useful in a fight. Doing both is a possible but serious compromise,

One of the problem I have with the team building is that the UI is a bit awkward and it took me almost an entire run through the game before I had a clear enough understanding of the game mechanics to optimize my team carefully. There are a few dimensions to the game system (roll to hit, damage reduction, peircing damage ignore part of the armor, bio-damage do damage in the long run, ...) which are all pretty much independent in the character sheet. It is sometimes hard to see how much point to spend in one aspect. Fortunately, you can "respec" your units from scratch between battles, so if you misunderstood the impact of a game mechanic, you can correct your team building mistakes for the next battle.

In term of difficulty, there are many difficulty levels. I play a lot of tactical games and normal was too easy for me. If you are used to that kind of games, push it one notch up. Though, it seems that at higher level, there is perma death, so... be careful.

I really liked some of the options in the game. Soldiers can use "overwatch" to cover some squares of the map and shoot enemie entering the zone. hydras can use napalm to set some squares of the map on fire causing damage to units passing through. Engineers can build turrets to defend some parts of the map. So overall, I feel like as a player, your decision can shape how the skirmish unfols.

One thing that could be annoying is that the ennemies can pop out of many places with no way for you to know in advance, and they usually play in the turn they appear. So you can get in situation where a unit pops out and deals you damage without much you could have done. (overwatch can be useful there.)

I find that the units you control have a very limitted field of vision. And sometimes, this can be very annoying.

Something good is that the game developpers are quite responsive. I don't know how long they will be maintaining the game. But for now, they reply on the forum almost immediately. I pointed out a bug that was essentially fixed in a day. They take suggestion.

The storyline is pretty much irrelevant. I do not feel like you have a clear control of the story nor a clear idea of the lore of the game. It is a fairly straight forward story, with a bit of details if you want to know more. Clearly the story is not the focus of the game. Overall, I feel like it is appropriate for this type of game.

The graphics are alright. It is a seen from atop game. Nothing fancy, but it works. The graphic style is nice and enjoyable. I appreciated the fact that the style is overall coherent, many smaller games tend to have incoherency in style. But this one is profesionnal.

In term of sounds, the sfx are appropriate, but the background music sucks. The music is really subpar in this game. One of the track is pretty much a mix of a 8-second track with a 16-second track. The others are not much better. It drove my wife crazy. Fortunately, you can shut the music off and leave the sfx, and play your own music in the back. Makes the game much more enjoyable.

In summary, is this game perfect ? no. Is it the best tactical game out there? no. Is it fun and enjoyable? Yes. Is it worth its price? Absolutely.

Absolutely phenomenal turn based combat game. Templar Battleforce is a love letter to games like Space Hulk and the early days of X-COM. 

You play as a group of superhuman, genetically enhanced warriors who are protecting a newly colonized section of a vast interstellar empire. Imbued with the ancestoral memories of your templar ancestors, it is your duty to beat back the unreleting hordes (and they really are hordes) of Xenos scum looking to make a meal of you.

Gameplay consists of top-down, turn based combat. You command a small squad of templars in a manner very similar to the original X-COM. Unlike your crysalid-bait rookies, (and more like Space Hulk) your templars have tremendously powerful skills and infinite ammo. The downside is that both abilities and weapons generate heat, as does movement, forcing you to pick which targets to kill, but to decide when as well. Overwatching a bridge swarming with xenos may provide excellent fire support, but the resulting weaponsfire may also overheat your critically toatsy templar.

Also like Space Hulk, you are always completely and totally outnumbered in Templars Battleforce. Enemy reinforcements are infinite, and many battles are fighting advances or retreats against mounting waves of foes. This makes for some surprisingly intense combat, and will definitely give your grey matter a workout. Do you split your forces into two advancing teams to get to the objectives faster? Do you leave one behind at the beacon to wait for your own reinforcements? Do you hold at the beacon until you are at full strength and hope it is sufficient to beat back the mass of xenos that have arrived?

The game also rewards quick mission times with greater experience, giving incentive to take risks. However, your troops are persistent, as is death. Don't spend your Templars unwisely. 

TLDR: 

If you're a fan of Space Hulk, X-Com, or Turn-based Strategy, you can't go wrong with Templars Battleforce.

21789078.review:
Templar Battleforce is a top-down, turn-based strategy title evoking memories of Laser Squad (forerunner of the original UFO: Enemy Unknown).  

The game is essentially a linked series of missions interspersed with squad and tech management, plus a smidge of storytelling.  The units under your control, the eponymous Templars, are not entirely dissimilar to WH40k Space Marines, being humans piloting suits of battle armour that augment their abilities.  The twist here is that rather than having a concept like 'gene-seed', a Templar's memories and experiences are passed down through their bloodline across generations.

Anyway, enough of the fluff.  The meat of the game - the tactical battles is competently done; movement and combat is handled via a variation of the time-honoured action point system and works intuitively.  Most missions seem to have a turn goal - completion of the objective within this will bestow extra experience, and this mechanic - coupled with a large sprinkling of risk/reward secondary objectives and tactical points to capture -  can lead to some nail-biting mission climaxes. 

There are excellent customisation options available for your Templars in between missions too, an RPG-lite skill and talent progression system for them to work through and  a very detailed tech tree which you unlock parts of by using the 'resource points' tallied up at the end of each battle.  Contained within the tech tree (which in terms of presentation reminds me of Sword of the Stars 1) are many weapons (some unique), abilites and miscellaneous items all of which allow for many varied takes on a Templar squad's makeup.

Graphically the game is serviceable and has improved with recent patches.  The audio is functional but nothing to write home about.  If I had one niggle it would simply be the relatively minor suggestion that the game lacks a little polish - there are points at which grammatical/spelling errors crop up in some of the story text for example and while I freely acknowledge that these are far from game-breaking, they do nonetheless pull me out of my 'zone' in the game and bring me back to reality with a bump.

All things considered (including the fantastic support Trese brothers continue to lavish on the game) I would heartilty recommend this title to anyone who enjoys turn-based squad level combat.  It's probably the closest we'll ever get to a genuine turn-based WH40k game, yet it does have its own distinct and well-developed lore.  Blend this with some brilliant research and management options then ask yourself - what more could you want for the price?

So, these are my thoughts on this game. I will not go into the gameplay or -mechanics in detail, other reviewers already did that extensively. I bought this game a while ago after noticing it in my steam queue and browsing the reviews (esp. vintoks' and Arkelis' recommendations I found very appealing). Played it for a bit and dropped it for XCOM2. Now I am back at it and that alone should tell you something.

[b]The Good:[/b]
+ It's been said before, this is the game Space Hulk wanted to be and failed at.

+ The game is very accessible, I consider myself to be a filthy casual when it comes to squad tactics games and I knew my way around pretty quickly without reading a manual. The tutorial is excellent in that regard and tooltips are really helpful. All the powers/actions are adequately explained and those explanations are easily accessible from all the relevant screens.

+ The game mechanics allow for a very good scaling of the difficulty level. I have only played on normal yet (which isn't too much of a challenge even for me *yet*) but I took a peek at other difficulties and the heat distribution of your armor alone requires more planning on your part on the higher ones.

+ I enjoyed the tactical challenges and diverse missions I have encountered so far and I don't miss the hilariously aggravating RNG of XCOM 2 for one second.

+ Customization of your troopers helps identifying and becoming invested with them, as far as you can get invested in something without a personality (your Captain is the sole exception there, as he actually talks) ;).

+ The ability to - at any point between missions - completely and freely respec any character is brilliant and invites you to experiment without having to start a new character. This is (for me) a serious long term enjoyment factor.

+ Same goes for the diverse equipment options you can unlock for your Templars.

+ Various troop specializations give you a wide variety of tactical options (once you unlock the relevant classes in the requisition tree).

+ The story is nice, if not very surprising or unexpected, especially when you are a 40k aficionado like me.

+ The devs. If you read - for example - the negative reviews, you might have noticed, that each one has a calm, objective comment, addressing key gripes of the reviewer where those where recognizable. Frankly I have yet to see something like that anywhere else on Steam (didn’t do ALL the research here tho, so do not make that into a gospel, please). At the same time there is still tweaking and improving of the game going on, months after the official release. And I am not only talking bugfixes, but also new skins and general improvements lesser people would hide behind a DLC.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
Things I didn't like with the game(play) itself, as opposed to outside appearances (see The Ugly). I am struggling with this a bit, since I pretty obviously enjoyed the game so far. Also I haven't finished it yet, but I wanted to get a positive review out as small games really can use those. So I might come back later and add to this here, but for now, this is what I got. As of now, none of them are anything major, just small annoyances:

- While there are secondary objectives to a mission, I haven't yet found a way to actually discover what they are without stumbling across them accidentally on the map. This clashes with the bonus you get for completing a mission in as little time as possible. That may be intentional, but I'd like the opportunity to decide beforehand if my squad should rather try for secondary objectives or speed. As it stands I don't even positively KNOW if there are secondary objectives at all most of the time (mostly there are, I think, but there seems to be no way to know beforehand) and this leads to a tendency to do a mission twice, once to chart the map and once to actually progress the campaign. Again, this might be intentional, but me no likey.

- There are opportunities to pick up loot from containers during a mission. You can recognize those by the coloring of their adjacent fields. This I discovered accidentally, it would have been nice to get a hint towards this in the tutorial. Also it seems there is a limit on how often this works during one mission, because I had times when I had already picked something up and then further containers I came across didn't give me anything (again a little annoying, because of wasted turns to get there). This too would be nice if it was mentioned somewhere, I haven't found a hint in that regard yet.

- Sometimes the dialogue options between the missions don't make it sufficiently clear that picking them will start a certain mission and close off other options.


[b]The Ugly:[/b]
- If you are looking for eyecandy, this might not be the game for you. The devs did good (and upgraded it noticeably a short while ago), but it can't hold to current standards. And why should it? It is an Indie game, catering to your tactical needs, graphics are a secondary means to that end at best.

- The soundtrack, yeah same. It is ok, but we are pampered by AAA games in that respect. I personally turned it off after a while and have something playing in the background (I hear all the cool kids do that these days anyway).

- No voiced narrative or characters. It's all reading here. That is no problem for me but it bears mentioning.

- The action, hmm. Action and round based strategy? Yes possible (see XCOM(2)), but imo more of the eyecandy category.

[b]tl;dr:[/b] 
I enjoyed (and still enjoy) this game a lot. I regard it as a real gem in the huge dungpile of bad games that Steam can be. If you like turn based squad-tactics you should check it out. If you like a 40k-esque setting,  even more so. If you bought Space Hulk and were disappointed by that, buy this game! Seriously!

The price tag is immensely reasonable. I have spent more money on some boardgames I put away after one evening. I already got my money’s worth out of this and am still going.

21275948.review:
[h1]Trese Brothers Rising[/h1]

Templar Battleforce is a polished indie turn-based squad tactics game with base building and RPG elements, set in the Trese Brothers' original Star Traders universe. It's a great game by a great developer. The Trese Brothers, long-time veterans of tabletop tactics games, got their start developing games for smartphones.  They have since produced numerous games exploring multiple genres in a short handful of years. Templar Battleforce represents a return to their stated mission: the creation of high-quality, multi-platform RPGs and Strategy games, supported by strong community involvement and a commitment to lifelong game updates.  All of their games fulfill this vision in some manner, but Templar Battleforce checks every box.  Furthermore, in creating Templar Battleforce, the Trese Brothers have used the lessons learned over their first few years as a fledgling studio to re-envision and re-invent the spirit of one of their earliest games- Templar Assault. It's a great feeling to play a game that is an indie dev's dream made real.

[h1]A Different Grim, Dark Future[/h1]

Before I discuss gameplay I'd like to address a common criticism of both the Star Traders universe and the Steel universe (Trese Brothers' fantasy setting).  The Trese Brothers have time and again explicitly recognized the Warhammer and WH40K settings as major inspirations for their work.  They also acknowledge many other sources of inspiration for their original settings.  Are the Trese Brothers' settings derivative? Yes. Does that make their settings rip-offs? No.  Point me if you can to a fantasy or spce opera setting in a game that is [i]not[/i] derivative, because I've never seen it.

The Trese Brothers settings combine common tropes in original and compelling ways, building an internally consistent universe on the foundation of inspiration.  Yes, some devs cut & paste together bits and pieces from popular settings.  The result is a lazy pastiche of improbable bedfellows, without depth or heart.  The Trese Brothers are clearly heavily invested in their settings, and as a result the world-building is unique, coherent, and immersive.

[h1]Every Leviathan Armor is for You, Templar. Which One Will You Make Your Own?[/h1]

Gameplay is divided into two primary components: missions and combat, and HQ activities.  The game features features a branching storyline that is tense and dramatic without being overbearing.  You will encounter story dialogue during most missions, but it rarely lasts longer than a handful of sentences.  The combat is top-down and grid-based.  Each Templar has a set number of Action Points (AP) and Movement Points (MP) derived from their base attributes.  The bottom of the screen displays an action hotbar, portrait, and HP and Heat bars for the selected Templar. Actions use AP and generate Heat. If MP is available acting will consume that as well, so it's often prudent to move everyone first and then go back have each one act.  If the Heat meter fills the Templar will not be able to use hotbar abilities. If it overfills they will take damage. Luckily, taking no action dramatically cools the armor.  Cover, line of sight, smart ability use, and overwatch are key elements of success.  The math feels polished, precise, fair, and detailed.  Many maps contain multiple main and secondary objectives; you will rarely play a "Kill All Enemies" mission.

Between missions you manage your squad at the HQ screen. It looks like a base-building interface but there's actually very little of that.  Instead, this is where you choose how to level each character, hire new characters, and requisition new items and abilities.  It's a class-based paradigm, with each class having access to unique skill trees and equipment.  Each level attribute and skill points are distributed manually, allowing for enormous flexibility and diversity.

Perhaps my favorite piece of the HQ experience is the requisition tree.  You earn RP by completing objectives, which you can then spend on an astounding array of global unlocks. Many of the unlocks are class-specific, and the skill-tree paradigm means getting the unlock you want first requires unlocking everything below it.  This is where the game requires careful consideration of your own gameplay style- you can't just unlock everything, you have to choose.  Of course this aspect also adds to the games replay value.

[h1]Thus, my Recommendation...[/h1]

If you've enjoyed other Trese Brothers games, you will definitely enjoy this one.  And as always the Trese Brothers offer the game attentive and continuous support.  I don't know of any other studio as endlessly committed to improving every product they release.  If you are new to Trese Brothers games, Templar Battleforce is a great place to start your journey.  

I recommend this game for all fans of turn-based squad tactics or of space opera RPGs.  I also recommend this game to almost anyone else, because it both imminently accessible and thoughtfully compelling.

[b]Templar Battleforce: 8/10
Trese Brothers: 10/10[/b]- an all around class act.

Short summary this game is a brilliant squad turn-based RPG. One of the best ones in my opinion.

There is too many features to list them all here, from the tact points, reinforcements and the excellent overwatch system.
You get attached to your customised templars and beg for miracles when one is getting swarmed.
The campaign is long, I don't feel like I've even scratched the surface of it. It is full of choices, go this way? Help these people? The game/story is well written and it's an interesting universe the devs have created. The art is actually quite nice, and  you can zoom in close during battles. The sound is well done and it really adds to the atmosphere.
The devs are really active, really supporting their games and easy to communicate with.
Honestly I couldn't recommend this game higher, it's a bargain at it's price.

The game has complex systems at work in the background but it is really easy to understand and learn.
Do youself a favour and pick this one up, it's an overlooked gem for sure.

I love this game.
This easily compares to the experience of the SNES Front Mission game. The writing is beautiful space-knight chivalry and politics, and works well into the scenario design. There are many levels of difficulty, no doubt there's one that's right for most any player.
The interface design can be a little overbearing with the visual bluntness of it, however it's very intuitive.

This is a game with somewhat complicated mechanics going on in the statistics, and it also fully explains all of them. Contrasting this with many other games that leave the players in the dark about finer points for the sake of appearing simple, this game spells out all its rules for the player in the help area.

The tactical play is solid. Templars have battle armor that generates heat with every move and action, and dissipates every turn. They take damage from overheating and lose access to some abilities, so this is literally a set of rules where "every move counts".

There may be a nuance or two that leave something to be desired for some people. The permadeath is relatively gentle and squishy - new recruits are free and infinite outside of battle, come at a percentage of captain level (depending on difficulty setting), and can be respec'd and redesigned freely - so you never really "lose" a soldier, just some negligible amounts of experience(perhaps less negligible on harder settings). The soldiers in your roster are just ready-to-deploy sets of specs and loadouts so you don't have to use the random stuff on new recruits in battle(though that'd be an interesting alternate way to play).

One might also say that some of the 8 soldier classes are too similar. Three of them are just gunners - gunners that are mostly offensive, gunners that are strictly offensive and use flame attacks(though the fire trails can be defensive), and gunners that emphasize overwatch, grenades and buffs. Many of the classes have limited gear options and the choice isn't about how you build that class, just using it or not (gee, do I want my guy that generates a lot of heat to have gear granting greater max heat? yeah probably). Other classes have a big variety of useful abilities and it pays to have two of them that are specialized differently, so it feels like some of the classes got the short end of the design effort.

Despite this I do NOT think the tactical decision making in the game leaves anything to be desired, the choices all impact the game. I find myself agonizing over the simplest stat growth choices.

20177060.review:
Simple and efficient well-crafted turn-based game.

[b]Game's description[/B]

You play with a small squad (from 3 to 12 members). There is more or less 40 missions. You usually need 10 to 20 turns to finish missions. (I would say 20 min to 1h30 per mission?)

There is 8 distinct kinds of soldiers (captain, scout, engineer, paladin, berserk, etc...) You chose how they progress after each mission : skills points and attributes points, how you equip them and which talents you learn or improve, depending on soldier's class. (For example: strike harder with blade or gun, strong short range shooting or long range, personal or mass boost -defensive or offensive-, more movement points, cover, radar, healing, attacks with penalties for ennemies, turrets, more abilities uses, capture, repair, etc...)
Before each mission, you can freely re-attribute skills points, attributes points and talents points, to modify you soldiers as you need.
There is a big development's tree used to chose which classes you will improve, which gears and abilities you will unlock, and which items you will be able to use. There is a lot of separate branches, and you cannot reset this tree, so your "battleforce" really depends on it.
You can entirely  create and chose which soldiers you use during missions, even if sometimes some soldiers or some classes are forced on. All soldiers progress during the game, even if soldiers you use a lot progress faster.

There is a "capture tactical points" mechanism in many levels. With tactical points, you can deploy new sodiers in mission, get new items to help you, and you usually want to protect it. It's not the core of the game (you don't do so many captures or deployments), but it's definitely a big part of the gameplay.

There is a totally black "fog of war", so you have to explore and discover maps, ennemies and objectives.
There is sometimes secondary objectives (places to go) on maps to get more xp, but usually you don't know if there are secondary objectives in a mission, and you don't know where it is.
The game push the player to move quickly and to kill a lot. The less you need turns to beat a mission (and the more you kill per turn), the more you receive XP.
There is small randomness in ennemies'creation.
There is no randomness for maps. So, if you retry a level, you will know what to do and where to go.

Sometimes (not too many), you have to do some choices, so the order of mission will change... and you can't do all missions in one playthrough.
When you finish the game, you can start again with your team and stronger ennemies to continue your progress.
The game saves automatically every turn. (So if you quit during a turn, you will have to start again. It can be useful if you did a bad move.) You can never save by yourself. During a mission, or at the end of a mission, you can restart the mission. (Except for ironman mode.)

The combat system is relatively complex, but there is an in-game "library" to briefly explain all concepts... if you want understand. There is some tutorials missions, to explain really basic stuff.
There is randomness during fights. Even if you can definitely influence it, and you can probably deal with it, the difference between a strong critical hit and a dodged one is obviously big.
You have to deal with a "heat" mechanism which inflicts damage if you do too many actions every turns.

There is a story and a universe around the game. You learn it mainly by talking with 2 or 3 NPC between missions. (You can skip it.)


[b]Personal opinion[/b]

I like turn-based games, and I enjoyed this one. It was fun to play, to find the best solution, to improve my soldiers, to discover the game. I liked different kind of soldiers and different abilities. Even if it's "simple", I think that the team successfully diversify missions. There is a lot of interesting soldiers, talents, gears and items, and the game is still well-balanced.
I liked to be able to play an entire mission in small game's session... and to know the length of a mission before I start it, based on the turns goal.

Personnally, I'm not fan of all mechanisms. (If I want more xp, I have to play fast rather than safe... I don't like the fog of war most of the time, because for some level you need to know the map to make best tactical decisions... The development's tree is big, with a lot of branches, so you cannot enjoy all classes during a playthrough, it's a little bit sad... You have to play always with same soldiers if you want the best progress for them, so you can't easily try all of them... It seems that the best way to play is to focus on some abilities and to avoid overheating, so you don't have enough talents points and heat to really use all interesting talents during fight.) But it's just details! The game is well crafted, the small team behind the game seems to be nice, so I can easily recommand this game, if you like this kind of game and if you liked what you saw in videos and screenshots.

Definitely, it's for people who like turn-based tactical games.

The templars are a rustic metal, while the Xeno seem like they're straight out of a circuit board.

Gameplay: Plays like most tactical strategies, you can only move so much each round and attack. This game takes a different kind of system, where if you attack before moving, your AP gets removed from your movement as well. Each of the different classes have armor and weapons you can equip between chapters. But the catch is you have to use the Requisition tree to unlock them. It also is where you unlock the more advanced units. This makes each playthrough interesting as you cannot really unlock all of the features in each playthrough.
