Where do I begin with Templar Battleforce? This lovely little game first caught my eye when I was trolling around the internet looking for video games that gave me the ability to play customizable soldiers clad in epic battle armor. This little gem caught my eyes and I've been hooked ever since.

In Templar Battleforce, you play an elite force of genetically modified humans who are capable of cognizant recall of their ancestor's memories. They, along with a convoy of more "all natural" human beings have fled the core of the galaxy to seek their fortunes, and survival, after an epic war ravaged their homeworlds in a past war. They come under attack during their exodus and are forced to make landfall on a set of desert worlds. From here, the story of the Templars truly begins.

In this game, you will control a customizable taskforce of Templar warriors. Your force is broken down into multiple different unit types: Your "Blade Class" Captain (Basically, the proper Player Character), Soldiers, Scouts, Engineers, Hydras (Flamethrower equipped heavy infantry), Neptunes (Autocannon/HMG equipped heavy infantry), Paladins and Berzerkers. Each class evolves as you spend a limited pool of requsition points to unlock new abilities, equipment, and options for your units.

The Requisition Tree deserves special mention because of how in depth it is. Every class has no less than three branches they can develope along, and given the relative rarity of the requisition as a resource, you will have to carefully mold your taskforce, selecting which classes and which abilities you desire to define your Templars with. Will you try for a generalist approach, taking each class and combining the smaller number of individual powers to create a greater sum than the whole? Will you focus on one or two classes, creating an army that is solid because of the uniform excellence of a Templar unit type? Will you stride into the battle with guns blazing, Neptunes holding the fort and laying down massive walls of firepower while the Soldiers press ahead and annhilating xeno scum with plasma blasters? Will you take up axe and sword, forming mighty shield walls while augmenting and healing your brothers and sisters in the middle of cyclone of melee combat? The choice is yours, and if you play the campaign through, New Game Plus will reward you for your diligence and victories in the face of defeat.

The campaign consists of a series of linked missions. This is where the meat of the gameplay is. Each mission will have its own objectives and peculiarities. While they tend to follow a fairly similar layout from one mission to the next (Kill enemies, survive against timers, take strategic points), each mission does in fact have its own peculiarities. You will cleanse infested landscapes with mighty flamethrowers, you will assault into alien ships to plant bombs in the core of the vessels, you will retreat through canyons and pver bridges while burning the earth during your retreat, you will investigate derelict space hulls, you will save desperate people from the middle of nightmarish scenarios, and you will secure cities against invading forces. Each of this mission types will come with their own peculiarities, their own specifics in terms of victory objectives, and each will have a larger place in the game's overarching plot. So, while the missions will have similar formulas, you will never truly play the same fight twice.

The mechanics on the field are rather simple at the end of the day. You have a topdown isometric perspective, wherein you command your units on a tactical grid. Movement points, action points, special attacks and abilities, unique battlefield requisition, and more will all be at your disposal. Each character is commanded individually, giving you the ability to maneuver your forces and utilize your strengths in strategic coordination. Soldiers can lay down fields of cover fire while your melee units advance, meanwhile your scouts move up ahead to find enemies and peg them with high powered sniper rifles or venomous needlers. Cap it off with your engineers setting up turrets to organize a defensive peremiter for your Neptune to hold with his suppressive fire so your strike force can advance deeper into enemy territory, and you'll find victory in your sights. Or do it another way. If you're familiar with tactical turn based squad games, then you will be right at home with Battleforce Templar, no matter your preference for command.

All of this is topped off with a world full of lore and personality that is revealed through the journal of your Captain and his/her interactions with the various NPCs you will meet in both missions and peaceful zones between campaigns.

Likewise, the music  tracks to this game, while somewhat limited in number, definitely set the tone for the missions. Each soundtrack is crafted with an emotional theme in mind, ranging from an uplifting ballad of defiant action against the enemy to stress inducing choruses that are played when the mission's stakes are high and the price of failure is higher.

Finally, the developer(s) for this game are actively improving upon their creation all of the time. Since I first obtained Templar Battleforce, there have been at least three full mini campaigns introduced, several revisions and additions to the Requisition Tree, expanded lore entries and dialogue options, expansions to enemy unit types, and a multitude of bug fixes, weapon rebalances, and class expansions. This is clearly a labor of incredible love from a dedicated company that wants to deliver the best experience possible to their customer base without shelving the cost of expanded content on their fans. They're doing this old school, and they're doing this right.

If you are a fan of Tactical Turn Based Strategfy games and love to support developers who put their player base first, this game comes HIGHLY recommended.

You spend AP by doing actions or you spend move points by moving. if you move first, you don't spend action points, but if you shoot first you spend move points. This means it's often better to stand firm and fire a whole bunch and encourages stationary combat. Which is good as well because the enemy is mostly melee. There are defintiely ranged enemies too though and there aren't just xenos, but they are the main enemy.

There's also a 'heat' system where if you take too many actions your templar can overheat and take damage. This restricts you from shooting and moving too much. 

I feel as though the 'requisition' system is neat too, but kinda makes me spread too thin. It's better to focus on a few classes, like 4 of them than to try and get them all. I also don't like that there is soldier and then heavy weapons because they function essentially the same. Paladin and berserker are similar too, but they have the distinction of being a healer and a pure melee which is nice, but there could be more variety in them.

The other classes are pretty varied though and quite fun to mess with. I like that engineers can lay turrets or specialize in capturing. Scouts can kite or be big hitters and armor penetrators or dedicated stealth scouts. Stealth works pretty uniquely too since it's not just 'turn invisible now you're invisible' but that you increase your stealth and stealth levels make you harder to detect. The only downside I can see is it's hard to tell if your guy is actually 'stealthed' since stealth levels reduce the range the enemy can detect you at. You kinda gotta manually do it?


Anyway I would definitely recommend the game. I like the game, the devs seem responsive in fixing bugs and adding in some content and making the game as a whole better. Some real love was put into the game and it makes the game even better as a result. I would like to see another templar game come out!

19095162.review:
TLDR; A good game that's worth buying for fans of turn based squad combat. Lot's of content, good class and progression system, flexible difficulty settings, rich back story, runs smoothly to boot.

If I had to describe this game in one word it would be: functional. There's no beautiful art or pretty effects, but what's is there gets the job done. The core gameplay is solid and the game runs smoothly, which to me is the most important thing a game has to get right before anything else.

Gameplay consists of turn based battles where you command a squad of space-marine-esque warriors called Templars. They come in various classes which gives them access to different abilities. The combat system can be a bit dense if you try to understand everything at once, but the game does a decent job off telling you what you need to know at any given time and if you really want to dig into the system there is a "Library" section that explains the game rules in detail. One thing I esspecially appreaciate about the interface is: tooltips, tooltips everywhere. Don't know what a stat does, just hover over it and a tooltip will appear and tell you what it feeds into, how likely am I to kill that alien?, hover over it and a tooltip will pop up giving you hit percentages and average damage.

In a game with a dense rule set like this I'm thankful that the devs made sure I could always quickly access enough information to make a decision and there are plenty of decisions to be made, both in and out of mission. Character progression consists of assigning points to their base stats, their special abilities(called talents) and giving them better gear. Below this is a requisition tree where you spend a requisition points to unlock new talents and equipment for your characters. I think this tree is very well planned out as it offers multiple ways to specialise your character classes, and many pieces of equipment can be used by more than one class, thus you can expand your options for other classes even as you level up only one. The limited amount of talent points each character gets means that you will inevitably create multiple characters of the same class and specialise them differently. For example: the scount class can be used as a fast stealth unit, or speced to be a high damage sniper.

The missions themselves are varied enough to be interesting. Most of the objectives consist of finding a thing or getting your entire squad to a certain place, but the map design and narrative keep this from getting boring. The game also provides a variety of difficulty settings from easy to the hardcore-permadeth-single-autosave difficulty for the ultra masochist. I have not finished the game yet but 18 hours in it looks like there's still plenty more content.

On the surface the game lore feels like it draws a lot of influence from Warhammer 40k, but I feel that it ultimately stands on it's own. Yes you have a force of elite warriors in mech-suits, yes you have a race of completely unsympathetic biological killing machines, yes you have cultists working to undermine humanity from within, but it's not like WH40k has a monopoly on these tropes and Templar Battleforce puts enough of it's own spin on them to keep things interesting. I find the concept of the Templar Lineage particularly fascinating.

The game's story is mostly delivered through text in "cutscenes" and through conversations in "secure areas"(missions where you can just walk around and talk to NPCs). This is fine if you don't mind reading text and enduring a little low budget storytelling. I think the devs did a decent job of breaking up the text and avoiding gratuitous exposition dumps, but your mileage may vary. If you really don't care for the story you can quickly skip over the text anyway.

My opinion on this game is summed up in the TLDR.  Make no mistake this is a niche game, but it does what it sets out to do. It's fun, polished and great value for money.

Honestly, I know nothing from the Star Traders universe, but I'm familiar with Warhammer 40k and StarCraft with their space marines. The Templars in this game hits the same chords : who doesn't like hulking machines decked-out in heavy weaponry ready to fire at every alien shenanigans they come by? On a more serious note : the Templars are really well done and diverse.  The lore behind them is also very interesting, and I love how it reflects into actual character customization. Demanding and Hard difficulties let you abort and retry your missions without penalty, but you can chose to carry on and accept the death of characters if you succeed the mission. So by all means, if you hesitate about buying this game, you shouldn't. If you are into tactical turn/squad-based games, you will like it. If you don't like that type of game then.. what are you exactly doing reading about it? :P

Summary for those who don't like to read:
Pros
-Solid mechanics
-RPG tactical
-The RP system

Cons
-No distinquishing features or mechanics from other members of the genre
    +The game seems to over rely on its own version of 'genetic memory'
-Terrible story telling that can't seem to keep track of what character's should know
-Unforgivable showing vs telling in a game with "Genetic memory"
-Bland unrelatable characters

I'd rank this game really as a 2 out of 5, barely. Mechanically everything works, but I don't find anything compelling in this game to, say, the game's from the UFO series, or even XCOM EU (and I hate that game). Or almost any other RPG tactical. Combat is pretty tame. You've got different points that award increased attack and defense to whoever holds them. A supply system that rewards you for holding tactical points with more characters on the field. Additionally, classes, talents, skills, etc which can be used to differentiate the different characters. There's also an RP upgrade system where you use points to unlock equipment, skills, etc. Also, the AI seems fairly straightforward so far, no twists, but it was early in the game (I doubt I'll have anything more to say on that). Together, it is solid, but if you search through most tactical games, you'll find most have a good chunk of the above in one form or another. However the dev's are still working on the game and we could see mechanical improvements. And besides that I hear what you're saying, "But dark, that's no reason to rate the game 2 out of 5, it should be at least a 3 out of 5 for these reasons!"

Well, my astute audience, my main issue is with the story. Some other reviewers are going, "OMG, the story is brilliant! Buy the game!" Obviously I disagree. For starters, I find the very idea of "Genetic memory" to be laughable. Might as well go, "Magic" (I'm doing jazz hands, fyi). But I gave the game a chance and set aside how silly that concept is. No, despite that, my main issue is that the dev's seem to be wishy washy about this "Genetic memory" and memory of the ancestors thing. In one scene, for instance, our main character 'knows' that a big baddy will come through a gate and so tells everyone in the party that it will occur. My immediate response was, "Wait, what?" At one point or another every person in your party would've had an ancestor that probably witnessed this sort of event so why the devil is our protagonist saying that? Are they just that kind of annoying a**hat? Wouldn't it make more sense to just do ancestoral flashbacks that way we get the info and it can be cool at the same time (show vs tell, devs)? Ugh, anywho, when the big bad does pop out what it is has to be explained to the protagonist via helper helpington (or reddish shield guy if you prefer). This isn't to mention how annoying it is when we're told a whole bunch of history to things that our character was indirectly a witness to.

And I can hear the buzz of the annoying uncritical fanboys, "But we get to make chhhooooiiiccccessss!" Okay, okay, sure, but the game has essentially murdered my interest in it at this point with these crimes against story telling and no amount of 'choice' makes up for that. Especially since this isn't the first game to do "You've got choices now!" Bland emotionless characters aren't helping either (at least at this point). Of course, the ultimate sin is that we're 'told' about this lineage. I don't see why we couldn't have an overarching family/lineage tree in the UI somewhere to give us all of the backstory. Even give all of those non-descript recruits a place in that tree. Seems like a better idea than what is currently in game. I imagine there should even be a few family feuds in there. This "Genetic memory" thing could be intriquing if done right, as it is, its a snore fest with no mechanical traction to get us anywhere to the more interesting points.

Anywho, I'm certain a solid chunk of peeps are all going, "Pft, I don't care about any of that," or "You're totally missing the point, X and Y and Z happens!" To the first, okay, but there are people that do. To the second, I don't really care. At this point the game has failed from a story telling perspective and in major unforgivable ways. I came in wanting to see what would transpire and now I no longer do. The writing up to this point is crap and the mechanics weren't enough to tide me over until X or Y or Z. So, for those like me, where story can make or break a game, this game, as it is now, is not worth buying.

Унылая индюшатина с закосом под атмосферу WH40K (только с закосом, сама никаким краем к вахе отношения не имеет). 

Играть нам в ней предлагается за фракцию религиозных фанатиков-милитаристов, что разъезжают на Больших Человекоподобных Танках (ака Левиафан сьют) и молятся своему пророку с игривым именем Шалун.

Дерево прокачки армии есть. Особым разнообразием не отличается. 
Т.е. как,... узлов в нем аж пара сотен, но не подумайте, что это пара сотен скилов или серьезных апгейдов солдат. Кастомизация персонажей есть, но минимальна.

Т.е. особо жалеть личный состав причин нет.


Вообще весь игровой процесс неспешен и скучен.

Все бои похожи друг на друга как две капли воды. Всегда врагов на порядок (раз в 10) больше чем нас, а чаще всего они просто бесконечны. Враги всегда лезут со всех сторон. Графика примитивна до зевоты, (хоть в данном жанре не это главное).
Музыку лучше отрубить сразу (и черт бы и с ней).

18654317.review:
I love this game. Have thoroughly enjoyed playing 23+ hours so far and I think I'm about halfway through. Bottom line, if you're into squad based combat games, and don't need fancy graphics, this game is for you. It's kind of like XCOM but without the stragteic base management, instead the strategic management is more about spending your xp wisely, equipping your troops correctly, and unlocking the parts of the trees that your soldiers need to upgrade gear/abilities.

I hope these guys come out with an expansion, or another game. They have got everything right from the actual gameplay perspective, all they need is a little more polish on the graphics (better and more varied animations, a bit better UI) and sounds, but those are just a matter of getting better assets, not a fundablement problem with the game.

Good
* Writing is crisp and impactful without delivering walls of text. You also don't have to read pages of exposition up front, the game drops you in the middle of the action and the story without the need to explain everything up front. If you don't mind learning-as-you-go (I really enjoy it) then it's a great experience.
* Excellent balance of difficulty, fun, and excitement. I've felt challenged on most levels (occasionally I breeze through one), and even lost a few levels.
* The equipment and leveling up systems are great. You unlock gear through a requistion process, but you don't buy individual pieces, instead you can then assign it to any soldier. When you level up you get to assign 2 different and independent stats while leveling a talent which are the abilities you can use in game.
* The soldiers classes feel /very/ different from each other and there are about 10 of them. Even small loadout changes can really flavor how they behave and operate on the battlefield. You also have a lot of choices on how you want to mix/match meele/ranged.
* The game doesn't reward you for "farming" during the mission at all. Get in, get the job done as quickly as possible, and keep your soldiers alive. You get extra xp and requsition points for doing the right thing (not for sitting at a spawn and camping).
* The in-mission replenishment system is great. You defend control points and those give you supply points which you can use to purchase stuff like medpacks. These control points aren't in every map, and generally if there are any you have to bring an Engineer.
* The mission flavors are great. I always feel like I'm doing something new. They do a great job of mixing up "defense, escort, push, speed, explore" kind of maps. I have actually picked out different flavors of teams based on that. The size of your team also changes, and there are occasionally NPCs that come with you (which can be a fun way to play with a class you haven't unlocked through the requisition system already).
* The mechanics of the game are great, and there's a lot of stuff in the character page that helps explain stuff. I would comment that it's kind of hard to get a feel for if you're pumping a stat too hard. IT would be nice to see the dice rolls and calculations which drive the game so that you could get a better idea if you've put way too many points into accuracy.

Bad
* The sound effects are pretty terrible. The music is OKay, but the gunshots and alien damage noises are really repetitive and often times I have a hard time telling what they are suppose to be.
* There is no "walk range" indicator that shows you what tiles you can move to. This also becomes a problem when you're starting out on a new tileset because it can be hard to tell which tiles you can move onto. You basically just have to experiment.
* Graphics are barebones and animations are a little stiff as well as having exactly one animation for each action. No idle animations either. It's servicable, but not great.

[h1] Suit Up for Tactical Greatness ![/h1]

Templar Battleforce is a very engaging and well thought out turn based Tactical RPG. It is a bit light on the roleplaying aspect but the action is amazing and has a ruleset that blows away the simple but punishing nature of games like the newest XCom's hit/miss mechanics. You will not find frustration by making the right decisions just to have your men screw up your tactical approach. But failure will come with bad choices or just a lack of battlefield visibility that you did not get, aka you can feel good that your loss is your fault in this game and not the dice. I have put together a couple of lists of things you can do in this game and why it is cool.

Before I get into the details, I'll cut straight to the chase with some stuff that wow'ed me:

[list]
    [*]A scout who does not have to be long ranged but I can use his massive movement to sneak up and melee troops down quickly or have him cripple enemy movement long-distance before my soldiers mop him up with overwatch fire
    [*]Overwatch fire from soldiers is a big field I set down where enemies who move into the square get shot ( for free, no action on my soldiers part) each time they move through the field, but they also clear a path for other enemies to go through, so you might have to have a couple of overwatch fields to get everyone, but the enemy does try to use this to their advantage.
    [*]I personally fell in love with the Hydra class the minute he set half of the battlefield on fire and I saw xenos running through them getting torched, only to fall to my overwatch fire or weakly attack my captain and then get slain by his free counter-attack.
[/list]

[h1] Tactical Character Customization[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Characters are outfitted by purchasing ranks in a tree tech system. It is a tree that splits each of the 8 classes into 3 distinct trees. You get points to buy them after each mission. This alone gives you the ability to customize and play whatever squad you want, in a way that you want. You can go crazy with a super tough melee oriented squad, or go sneaky long-range scouts, or just blow up the whole battlefield with Pyromaniac Hydras and grenade slinging soldiers.
    [*]Combat involves both melee and ranged and both are very good and compliment each other. Melee and ranged are both about positioning your men right. Since this is turn based, but has reaction type skills like Overwatch in it, you want to make it appealing for enemies to engage your melee who can counter-attack them, through your ranged overwatch fields. This is very fun to setup fire lanes and watch enemies fall before your organization.
    [*] Combat is about escalation and management of your forces and the enemies. Each map usually involves you trying to cut off the enemy forces before they outnumber you too greatly ( or your suits start frying your men because each action builds up heat that can damage you if it gets to high from using it). You can counter this by controlling choke points but the cool mechanic is that you can control tactical points to bring in more templars whose abilities might really help you out - a hydra to ignite the whole battlefield or another soldier to setup more overwatch lanes...or perhaps a stealthy scout to infiltrate and lock down another area where the xenos are pouring in from. This becomes a game within the game in a way.
[/list]

[h1] Rules System that is explained in game so you don't need to wiki everything[/h1]

[list]
    [*]Combat resolution is a system of D10 dice rolls made in game that are compared to your opponents opposing dice rolls. This distributed average of hit and misses makes sure that your characters and the enemies are not just getting lucky or unlucky.
    [*]There are no obvious dump stats when you level up your templars, the game does its best to make every stat important. Aggressive damage stats like Quickness also give you defense bonuses, stats like tactical influence how good your buffs from your men are but also give you critical hit advantages.
    [*]There are no crazy instant win abilities or stats. Every ability and stat plays into each other very well and makes you build a team of fully functional warriors who need each other.
[/list]

I know this was a long review, but damn, this game is great and I feel like I am only in the beginning still after 15 hours. I definitely look forward to conquering this game and then moving onto higher difficulties with a much better strategy.

[b]Small package, large game[/b]

I'd compare this to Templar Assault, but if you've played Templar Assault, you've probably already bought this game. 

If you haven't, Templar Battleforce is a grid-based, turned-based strategy game where you lead a squad (well, more like a platoon) of armored infantry across a variety of battlefields. While most "budget" tactical games either limit you to a handful of units with flexible progression or offer you a choice of otherwise bland troops with one unique trait apiece, Templar Battleforce gives you eight classes each with a broad selection of upgrades and gear that have minimal overlap with the other classes. Each of your soldiers levels up seperately and has their own stats and skills, making it easy to specialize even soldiers in the same class for different roles.

The scenarios are objective-driven, usually encouraging a fighting advance, though more defensive and other goals pop up. Maps do not seem to get reused, keeping things relatively fresh. Enemy variety is broad enough to encourage keeping your squad flexible, without becoming confusing. 

Graphics are in the screenshots. Clear and atmospheric, they are about what you'd expect from a 2D game made by three people. Similarly, the sounds and music are serviceable, if less than cinematic quality. Still, the strength of the game lies in the gameplay rather than presentation.

Replayability includes multiple difficulties, New Game+ modes, and the option of exploring different paths on the Requisition tree, which unlocks class upgrades and gear. While characters themselves can have their talents, skills, and attributes respecced freely between missions (an ability explained in the fluff), the requisition tree is less flexible.

I'm told there are about 50 scenarios, so I'd guess about 15-20 hours to blow through them all if you're an experienced gamer playing on Normal. 

All in all, Templar Battleforce is an excellent value for anyone who enjoys turn-based tactics games that mix relatively simple mechanics with plenty of options for customization and strategy.

Also, there's minimal randomness. While attacks can miss and criticals can happen, rarely is an individual attack going to make a difference in mission success.

18202806.review:
Between this and Renowned Explorers, it's been a surprisingly good month for indie strategy/rpg games.
This one has you take control of a squad of super powered troops, think 40k space marines and you'd feel very much at home. You take your squad through turn based missions not unlike Xcom tactical phase or Jagged Alliance (if you remember Laser Squad then that's an even better comparison) and the game uses both an AP and MP system as well as an overheating system (keep running around, firing wildly and using abilities wantonly will quickly overheat a Templar's suit and cook the pilot inside!).

MP+AP might confuse some people at first as AP uses up MP too, but it also allows you to take more complex moves then allowed in say..xcom unless you have a ton of perks. Ex: you can have a Templar throw a grenade for 1AP, fall back with remaining MP then end your turn by using up all your APs into firing action.
Combined with overheating, this means optimal use of your Templars can be trickier then it seems especially in hectic situations. If I'm making it out to be tedious though, rest assured, it isn't. It enhances gameplay and contributes to the feeling you are commanding a squad of walking tanks.


Inbetween missions you unlock equipment, abilities and new Templar classes in a tech tree of sorts as well as levelling up and gearing up your Templars. At first the options are limited as you'd expect, but you quickly start unlocking stuff and your Templars are able to carry more equipment as they level, increasing build flexibility as the game goes on.

The game can be played with ironman settings and permadeath if desired.

The best points of this game are definitely the squad development which is far more extensive then any other title of this genre I've played and lots of action, you'll quickly rack up hundreds of dead xenos. 

As a 40k fan I was quite partial to the design and feel of the Templars themselves too, a couple of missions has human enemies and/or allies and the difference between normal squishy humans and your power armored behemoths is quite satisfying.

Graphics is probably going to be the biggest barrier for people who care about that. Visuals are perfectly serviceable and clear and I like the blood splatter and gooey messes aliens leave, or for that matter the bloodied wrecks of dead Templars, but I recognize that people born a lot later then me might have more picky tastes so check out screenshots and see if that doesn't bother you.

Pros:
-Exelent rpg mechanics and squad development mechanics, so many games have the rpg tag yet have rather shallow level up mechanics and this isn't one of them. Tooling up your templars is just a joy in this.
-Linked to the above, you can respect stats and talents any time, so no fear of making "bad" builds and you can experiment more.
-Missions are nicely varied in the objectives and challenges you need to overcome.
-Great gameplay overall.

Cons:
-Graphics are clear and functional but unlikely to impress. Animations as well can be described as such.
-Apart from maybe 1-2 music tracks, don't recall the music to have been particularly memorable.
-There is a story and even some choices to make but this isn't really a game you play for the story. That said, I found the Templar lineage part of the background quite cool and liked how it justified respeccing Templars within the lore.

Overall as far as squad based tactical games go this is a really good title, 100% reccomend it.

18188730.review:
In a few words, Templar Battleforce is a 2D XCOM set in a backdrop that is heavily inspired by Warhammer 40k. It is somewhat rough around the edges but is surprisingly easy to get into if you have a general idea of what to expect.

The core tactical combat gameplay is very well done and even exceeds games like XCOM in some areas such as flexibility and variety. While the internal mechanics of combat suffer from the opaqueness of the dice rolls system and of the damage mitigation formula, the game offsets this with ample toolips and a set of starting missions which guide new players through all they need to know to enjoy the game. Extra praise is deserved for both the tooltips and tutorials as these two elements are rarely well done in indie games and are often quite mediocre in AAA releases.

Combat itself is familiarly intuitive and draws much of its allure from the fairly deep customization options and progression available. First off you have a sort of tech tree which controls the pool of equipment, active abilities, and recruitable templar classes available. Every templar in your band belongs to a class which defines which active abilities are available and which equipment can be equipped. In addition to equipment and talents (active abilities), every templar has two sets of defining statistics which can be increased by one point each level. You will end up customizing talents, equipment, and attributes for each templar every time he levels up which will be every 1-2 missions. This is so since you can freely respec any templar between missions and you will want to do this when new abilities or equipment become available, which happens almost after every mission depending on how you choose to progress the tech tree. This opens ups the ability to experiment freely with your squad build and keeps you from worrying too much about planning your progression ahead of time.

I was also very happy with the mission design so far (about 10 missions in). The length of each mission is right on target with about 30 mins on average and the overall pacing is excellent so far. The time I’m spending in mission and out of mission leveling my army is at a good ratio to prevent being fatigued with either aspect. The missions themselves don’t drag out with most missions aiming for around 15 turns on average to complete which keeps each turn and what you do in it very significant. The heat mechanic plays an important role here. Heat builds up from using abilities and moving and decreases a small amount each turn and will decrease a lot in a turn if no or almost no actions are taken during that turn. Maxing out on heat will start causing hitpoint damage to the templar so this helps keep the action tense makes you consider every action you take or don’t take during a turn.

I have a few small gripes with the game which affect my enjoyment of it in very limited ways. No ability to change keybindings is regrettable but not critical since the default scheme is workable if somewhat inconvenient. The way vision works could use improvement as your templars can only seem to see 5 squares away which can lead to very awkward ambushes. Enemies can attack the same turn they spawn which is annoying but since they don’t spawn in packs, for the most part, this is nowhere near as big an issue as it was in XCOM. There is plenty of room for the UI to be improved and enhanced with such features as moving the camera via mouse screen edge scrolling, highlighting interactable elements on mouseover, indicating which squares either your unit or an enemy unit can move to this turn or the enemy's next turn. The Devs have indicated that some of these fetures, edge scrolling in particular, will be added in future updates.

This is a game I would highly recommend to anyone who enjoys turn-based tactical RPGs in the style of the recent XCOM or going further back to Temple of Elemental Evil and Pool of Radiance. The story is very adequate for a game where the story is arguably not the main focus and works very well to build up the right atmosphere of tension and heroics and this is a type of game that benefits greatly from having that kind of backdrop. The ample depth of progression available for your “army” and each templar along with way the game encourages experimentation will keep most players hooked.

They are a credit to game development and how dlc and support of a game should be managed.

The big guns out there, could learn a thing or two from these guys.

The squad customization is truly inspiring, if a little daunting at first. 
What I mean by that is, you don't have AAA graphics here so the tons of equipment and various skills and talents throw lots of numbers at you instead, which can be the daunting part.
However, given a little time and some missions into the game you start to come to terms with it all and then you can't help but want to play more missions to earn more RP to get that new piece of equipment or unlock that new Templar type.

What I like most about building your Templars though, is the fact that you really feel the difference in the changes you make. 
A lot of games fail in that regard, you get excited about a new piece of kit or a skill and it proves totally underwhelming in actual combat. Not so here. 
You get a new sword and all of a sudden you're single hit killing those low level Xeno's that used to need two hits. 
Crowd control is a thing, and now your Templars are ready for it!

I feel the game also does a good job of satisfying the needs of players who like varying skill levels. I often see the arguments about casual and hardcore gamers now, well to me all games should be capable of supporting both by the use of difficulty levels. 
Trese Brothers have added many difficulty options to suit all players and each level has a good description of what it actually does so the player isn't left guessing and trying to figure it out themselves (Yet another thing the Brothers should be commended on).

The game does so much right and the Trese Brothers really have poured love and affection into their game and will continue to do so (for Free, I might add).

*Edit: All of the below minor complaints from me have been patched and fixed and the devs continue to update the game. Brilliant devs and they deserve huge credit for everything they do.*

The very few minor things I disliked or found confusing about the game are already being responded to and were the majority have voiced an opinion are being changed.

Things like the speed of text during cutscenes, I'm slowing down in my old age and I find I am having to rush to read which breaks immersion of the story for me. It confused me because during missions you have to click to forward text and I felt this should be the same for cutscene text.

During the starting missions of the game, before you really know what is going on, you are asked to activate a gate but the switch you use to do this just looks like any other map flavour tile and the fact you can click on it is not immediately obvious. 
I lost a few turns here, while thinking to myself, Alright I'm in the area you told me to go to, why isn't something happening? Because you didn't click the switch dumbass. Well it wasn't really that obvious game :D

The open and closed deployment before going into a mission confused me because whenever it said open I was clicking furiously around the screen for some way to take the Templars I wanted into the mission. 
Before I finally went to the forums and read that 'open' means you can get a control point in the mission which will allow you to call in more Templars as opposed to actually allowing you to take what you want from the beginning. 
And closed meant there would be no control point and what you get is what you have for the full mission. (This is something the devs are addressing and will be updated to allow you to take what Templars you want outside of what is actually needed for the scenario, like an engineer or scout etc).

Lastly the fact you left click on an enemy to see their stats but also left click on an enemy to attack them. 
In the later missions of the game it is important to watch your Templars heat and balance moving, damage and other various skills. 
So I often want to check the health left on an enemy to be sure I can kill it in another way before taking a shot with the same Templar again. 
The current system can lead to mistakenly taking shots or using a skill you did not want to. 
You can unselect your Templar or their skill before clicking on an enemy to avoid this but I feel it is a little clunky and could do with being changed.

As I said, these things are already been looked into by the Trese Brothers and overall I think they did an amazing job with this game.

I definitely recommend this game to anyone who loves Turn based strategy and squad building games and if you are new to the series and just dipping your toe in I couldn't fault you starting here.

Well worth a purchase.

I hope when the Trese Brothers grow into producing AAA titles they remain true to their current values and continue to price their games correctly and support them as they do now.

Thank you Trese Brothers.

I look forward to what I hope will be a very long and bright future for you in video games.
